multipartSettings.allCorrectMust: All parts needs to be correct
multipartSettings.anyCorrect: Any of the parts can be correct

helperText.itemLevelScoring: Automatically divide score equally between parts, there will be one score reported.
helperText.partLevelScoring: Manually specify the different scores for each part and report it separately.
helperText.allCorrectMust: Credit will be awarded only if all parts are completely correct.
helperText.firstCorrectMust: The first part needs to be completely correct in order for credit to be given on other parts. For example if the student gets parts 2 and 3 correct, but not the first part, they will get zero.
helperText.anyCorrect: Credit will be awarded if any part is correct based on how the part is scored
helperText.layoutStyle: Select the layout style that fits your item. The two column style with different sizes allow you to add a passage or resource on the left and one or more question parts on the right.
helperText.useTabs: Enable tabs on the left or right panel of the layout. This can be used in cases where you want to show multiple passages to the student.

component.enterHintForTheProblem: Enter a hint for the problem
component.correctItemNotAllowDynamic: Dynamic Parameter questions have their random values generated when the test is assigned, and they cannot be changed. You will have to grade these questions manually

helperText.variableType: Variables such as @a or @x can represent text, expressions or numbers.
helperText.combinationCount: Enter the desired number of combinations of the parameters.
helperText.NUMBER_RANGE: Here a random value is generated between the ranges specified. Specify the range using the min and max option. You can also specify the number of decimal places
helperText.NUMBER_SET: You can specify a set of numbers, and the values generated are numbers that are randomly assigned from the set
helperText.NUMBER_SEQUENCE: This option is useful with other dynamic parameters of sequence type. All variables of sequence type need to have the same number of items. The values generated are numbers/text picked out from each position in the sequence
helperText.TEXT_SET: You can specify a set of words (or any text), and the values generated are words that are randomly assigned from the set
helperText.TEXT_SEQUENCE: This option is useful with other dynamic parameters of sequence type. All variables of sequence type need to have the same number of items. The values generated are numbers/text picked out from each position in the sequence
helperText.FORMULA: You can specify a formula using other dynamic variables generated earlier. We recommened you use this as the variable in the input box because you can use the advanced math settings to control the formula output. Example: if you want the student's answer to be a fraction, decimal, etc.

pendingEvaluation.tooltip: App failed to evaluate due to unexpected input format

options.dynamicParametersDescription: To use dynamic variables in a question, use @ symbol ahead of the variable e.g. @x, @y etc. Once you have used the variables in the question text or correct answer, you should see them listed here. You can use a range, set or fomula to calculate these variables. Do not use @ prefix in this section alone.
options.invalidSeqVariableMsg: Please note that all dynamic parameters that are of "sequence" type need to have the same number of items. Otherwise, it may not be so obvious how the sequences should be aligned.
options.updateOrDeleteCustomKeypad: Update or Delete a Custom Keypad
options.title: Title
options.label: Label
options.subject: Subject
options.enterDistractorRationaleQuestion: Enter distractor rationale for the question
options.removePrevDynamicValues: This will clear all previously generated values. Do you wish to proceed?

showGridlinesOptions.both: Display X and Y axes gridlines

plain.templateText: The United States of America, is a federal republic composed of 50 states, a federal district, five major territories and various possessions.

rich.templateText: William Shakespeare was an English poet, playwright, and actor, widely regarded as the greatest writer in the English language and the world's...

shortText.smallSizeTitle: How many states are there in America?
shortText.smallSizePar: Write your answer in the text field below.

imageDragDrop.wrapTextToFitDropArea: Wrap text to fit drop area

graphing.title: Title

settingsPopup.gridCutoff: The minimum and maximum grid settings you have given can cause the axes numbers to be cut off the edge of the display. Please adjust them if you wish the complete axes to be displayed

graphing.pointsOnEquConfirm: If you choose this option, then the expected answer objects will be cleared. Do you wish to continue?

helperText.point: Select any point on the grid to draw a point.
helperText.segment: Select two points on the grid. A line segment will be drawn such that its endpoints coincide with the points selected.
helperText.polygon: Draw points on the grid that define the vertices of the required polygon. Make sure to close off the shape.
helperText.ray: Select two points on the grid. A ray will be drawn between the two points such that the first point selected would be its starting point.
helperText.vector: Select two points on the grid. A vector will be drawn between the two points such that the endpoints define its magnitude and direction.
helperText.line:
Select two points on the grid. A line will be drawn through them.

Example: If you select #{A=(0,0)#}, #{B=(1,1)#}, the line whose equation is #{y=x#} will be plotted.
helperText.circle:
Select two points on the grid. A circle will be drawn such that its center coincides with the first point, and it passes through the second point.

Example: If you select the points #{A = (0,0)#} and #{B = (1,1)#}, a circle whose equation is #{x^2+y^2=1#} will be plotted.
helperText.ellipse:
Select three points on the grid. An ellipse will be drawn such that its foci coincide with the first two points plotted, and it passes through the third point.

Example: If you select the points #{A(-4,0), B(4,0)#} and #{C(0,3)#}, the ellipse whose equation is #{\frac{x^2}{5^2}+\frac{y^2}{3^2}=1#} will be plotted.
helperText.parabola:
Select two points on the grid. A parabola will be drawn through them such that its vertex coincides with the first point drawn. Note that you can only draw parabolas whose directrix is parallel to the x-axis using this option.

Example: If you select the points #{A=(0,0)#} and #{B=(1,1)#}, the graph of #{y=x^2#} will be plotted.
helperText.parabola2:
Select three points on the grid. A parabola will be drawn such that its focus is the first point plotted, and its directrix is the line joining the remaining two points.

Example: If you select #{A = (0,0.25)#}, #{B = (-1,-0.25)#}, #{C = (1,-0.25)#}, the graph of #{y=x^2#} will be plotted.
helperText.hyperbola:
Select three points on the grid. A hyperbola will be drawn such that the first two points coincide with its foci and it passes through the third point.

Example: If you select #{A=(0,-\sqrt{2})#}, #{B=(0,\sqrt{2})#} and #{C=(1,0)#}, the graph of #{y^2 - x^2 =1#}, will be plotted.
helperText.polynom:
Select #{n+1#} points on the grid that lie on the desired polynomial curve of degree n. The required curve will be drawn through them. Note that you must click on the first point selected to draw the graph.

Example: If you select the points #{A=(-1,-1)#}, #{B=(0,0)#}, #{C=(1,1)#} and #{D=(2,8)#}, the graph of #{y=x^3#} will be plotted.
helperText.exp:
Select two points on the grid, say #{A = (x_1, y_1)#}, #{B = (x_2, y_2)#}. The following graph will be drawn: #{y = y_1 + \frac{y_2-y_1}{x_2-x_1}e^{x-x_1}#}

Example: If you select #{A = (0,0), B = (1, 1)#}, the graph of #{y=e^x#} will be plotted.
helperText.exponential2:
Select a point on the grid, say #{A = (x_1, y_1)#}.
The following graph will be drawn: #{y = e^{x\frac{ln(y_1)}{x_1}}#}

Example: If you select #{A = (1,e)#} the graph of #{y=e^x#} will be plotted.
helperText.logarithm:
Select two points on the grid, say #{A = (x_1, y_1), B = (x_2, y_2)#}. The following graph will be drawn: #{y = y_1 + \frac{y_2-y_1}{x_2-x_1}ln(x-x_1)#}

Example: If you select #{A = (0,0), B = (1, 1)#}, the graph of #{y=\ln x#} will be plotted.
helperText.sine:
Select two points on the grid. A sine curve will be drawn through them such that the first point lies on the midline, and the second point lies on the adjacent crest/trough.

Example: If you select #{A = (0,0)#} and #{B = (\frac{\pi}{2},1)#}, the graph of #{y = \sin x#} will be plotted.
helperText.cos:
Select two points on the grid. A sine curve will be drawn through them such that the first point lies on the midline, and the second point lies on the adjacent crest/trough.

Example: If you select #{A=(-\frac{\pi}{2},0)#} and #{B = (0,1)#}, the graph of #{y = \cos x#} will be plotted.
helperText.tangent:
Select two points on the grid. A tangent curve will be drawn such that the first point lies on a point of inflection, the value of the x-coordinate of the second point is the asymptote, and the y-coordinate representing the vertical stretching or "Amplitude" of the tangent function.

Example: If you select #{A=(0,0)#} and #{B=(\frac{\pi}{2},1)#}, the graph of #{y=\tan x#} will be plotted.
helperText.area: Select any point in a "closed" region of the graph that you require to be shaded (representing an inequality). This area will be shaded.
helperText.dashed:
This is used to represent dashed inequalities.
Example, to represent #{y < x#}, draw the line #{y = x#}, and select the appropriate shaded area. Then click on the line to make it dashed.
helperText.secant:
Select two points on the grid, say #{A=(x_1, y_1)#}, #{B = (x_2, y_2)#}. The following graph will be drawn: #{y = y_1 + (y_2-y_1)\sec\left({\frac{\pi}{2(x_2-x_1)}x-\frac{x_1\pi}{2(x_2-x_1)}}\right)#}
The geometric meaning is that the difference between the y-coordinates of the two points selected is the "Amplitude" and the difference between the x-coordinates is related to the period. The x-coordinate of the first point is related to the phase shift.

Example: If you select #{A = (0,0), B = (\frac{\pi}{2}, 1)#} will be plotted.
helperText.cotangent:
Select two points on the grid, say #{A = (x_1, y_1), B=(x_2, y_2)#}, the following graph will be drawn: #{y = y_1 + (y_2-y_1)\cot\left({\frac{\pi}{2(x_2-x_1)}x-\frac{x_1\pi}{2(x_2-x_1)}}\right)#}
The geometric meaning is that the difference between the y-coordinates of the two points selected is the "Amplitude" and the difference between the x-coordinates is related to the period. The x-coordinate of the first point is related to the phase shift.

Example: If you select #{A = (0,0)#}, #{B=(\frac{\pi}{2}#},1)#}, #{y=\cot x#} will be plotted.
helperText.cosecant:
Select two points on the grid, say #{A = (x_1, y_1)#}, #{B = (x_2, y_2)#} the following graph will be drawn:
#{y = y_1 + (y_2-y_1)\csc\left({\frac{\pi}{2(x_2-x_1)}x-\frac{x_1\pi}{2(x_2-x_1)}}\right)#}
The geometric meaning is that the difference between the y-coordinates of the two points selected is the "Amplitude" and the difference between the x-coordinates is related to the period. The x-coordinate of the first point is related to the phase shift.

Example: If you select #{A = (0,0)#}, and #{B = }\left(\frac{\pi}{2}, 1\right)#}, #{y=\csc x#} will be plotted.
helperText.piecewise_line: Draw a line and use the cutting tool to cut off sections of the line to create piecewise functions.
helperText.line_cut: Use this to cut off sections of a line or parabola to create piecewise functions.
helperText.rose:
To create a rose with an equation of #{r = a cos(kθ)#},
place the control point on #{(a, \frac{\pi}{k})#}
helperText.cardioid:
To create a cardioid with an equation of #{r = a(1 + cos(θ))#}, place the control point on #{(2a,0)#}.
To create a cardioid with an equation of #{r = a(1 - cos(θ))#}, place the control point on #{(2a, \pi)#}.
To create a cardioid with an equation of #{r = a(1 + sin(θ))#}, place the control point on #{(2a,\frac{\pi}{2})#}.
To create a cardioid with an equation of #{r = a(1 - sin(θ))#}, place the control point on #{(2a, \frac{3\pi}{2})#}.
helperText.polarWithArea: You cannot use Area with a Rose or Cardioid graph
helperText.fxWithArea: You cannot use this functionality after plotting a graph. This option is used solely for the purposes of exploring curves of complicated equations.
helperText.fxHepler: This is a teacher-only tool for exploring curves of various complex equations like #{y =\frac{1}{tan(x)}#}. For creating questions for your students, you should only use the predefined graphing objects.

math.ignoreOrder: Ignore order in comma separated list
math.allowNumericOnly: Limit the entry to numbers only
math.ignoreTrailingZeros: Ignore trailing zeros in a decimal
math.ignoreCoefficientOfOne: Ignore a "#{1#}" in front of a variable
math.compareSides: Compare both sides of the in/equality
math.isExponent: Check if variable is an exponent
math.isStandardForm: Check if equation is in standard form
math.isSlopeInterceptForm: Check if equation is in slope intercept form
math.isPointSlopeForm: Check if equation is in point slope form
math.compareStartAndLength: Length and start point both checked

helperText.evaluationSettings: Additional evaluation considerations, for example, if you require that the student's response is simplified, or meets a specific tolerance, or should be literally matched...
helperText.graphEvaluationSettings: Specify the additional checks that should be performed on the student's entry, such as to check the labeling of points, measure perimeter, area or parallel lines. Note that you can also incorporate background shapes or images with the advanced options menu on the left.
helperText.isSimplifiedFraction: The common factors should be removed. Note that if the expected answer is not a simple fraction, e.g. #{\frac{3}{6}#} then the grading will give errors.#{\newline[1em]\text{Correct:\enspace}\frac{1}{2},\quad\text{Incorrect:\enspace}\frac{3}{6}#}
helperText.isSimplifiedExpression: Less complicated form of an expression, for example the common factors should be removed and like terms grouped.#{\newline[1em]\text{Correct:\enspace}\frac{1}{2},\quad\text{Incorrect:\enspace}\frac{3}{6}\newline[0.5em]\text{Correct:\enspace}2x+y,\quad\text{Incorrect:\enspace}x+x+y#}
helperText.isMixedFraction: Form of an integer followed by a fractional part.#{\newline[1em]#} #{\text{Correct:\enspace}1\frac{1}{2},\quad\text{Incorrect:\enspace}\frac{3}{2}#}
helperText.isImproperFraction: Entry needs to be of the form of a/b where a>b #{\newline[1em]\text{Correct:\enspace}\frac{7}{4},\quad\text{Incorrect:\enspace}1\frac{3}{4}#}
helperText.isRationalized: There should not be any roots in the denominator.#{\newline[1em]\text{Incorrect:\enspace}\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}},\quad\text{Correct:\enspace}\frac{\sqrt{3}}{3} \newline[1em]\text{Incorrect:\enspace}\frac{1}{1+\sqrt{x}},\quad\text{Correct:\enspace}\frac{1-\sqrt{x}}{1-x}#}
helperText.isFactorised: Split into a product of simpler expressions. The opposite of Expanded.#{\newline[1em]\text{Correct:\enspace}(x+3)(x+1),\quad\text{Incorrect:\enspace}x^2+4x+3#}
helperText.isExpanded: Multiplied to remove parenthesis. The opposite of factored.#{\newline[1em]\text{Correct:\enspace}x^2+4x+3,\quad\text{Incorrect:\enspace}(x+3)(x+1)#}
helperText.isExponentialForm: Written as base with power of the number of repeats.#{\newline[1em]\text{Correct:\enspace}2^3,\quad\text{Incorrect:\enspace}8#}
helperText.tolerance: Student answer is acceptable if within this range. Can also use #{\%#} sign.#{\newline[1em]\text{Expected:\enspace}3,\quad\text{Tolerance:\enspace}2\newline[0.5em]\text{Correct:\enspace}4,\quad\text{Incorrect:\enspace}6#}
helperText.requireIntervalNotation: Range of real numbers, enclosed by rounded or square parenthesis.#{\newline[1em]\text{Expected:\enspace}(0,1]\newline[1em]\text{Correct:\enspace}(0,1],\quad\text{Incorrect:\enspace}(0,1)#}
helperText.numberType: Defines of a specific amount of something.#{\newline[1em]\text{Correct:\enspace}10,\quad\text{Incorrect:\enspace}x#}
helperText.integerType: A number that can be written without a fractional component.#{\newline[1em]\text{Correct:\enspace}2,\quad\text{Incorrect:\enspace}1.5#}
helperText.isDecimal: A whole number and a fractional part separated by a decimal point.#{\newline[1em]\text{Correct:\enspace}1.5,\quad\text{Incorrect:\enspace}1#}
helperText.scientificType: Way to write a very large or small number using powers of ten.#{\newline[1em]\text{Correct:\enspace}7.11E+2,\quad\text{Incorrect:\enspace}711\newline[1em]\text{Correct:\enspace}7.01\times 10^2,\quad\text{Incorrect:\enspace}701#}
helperText.significantDecimalPlaces:
A number expressed with sufficient digits that express the required precision. Please note that your Expected Answer must normally meet the same required decimal places and rounding as the students, except in the case of Dynamic Parameter formulas - here the system will do the implementation of the rounding and required decimal places in the expected answer. #{
ewline[1em]	ext{Expected:\enspace}0.20,\quad	ext{Decimal places:\enspace}2
ewline[0.5em]	ext{Correct:\enspace}0.20,\quad	ext{Incorect:\enspace}0.2
ewline[1em]#}Use alternate answers if you want to accept #{0.2#}, #{0.200#}, etc. Also, consider using tolerance if a range of answers is acceptable.
helperText.setDecimalSeparator: The separator of the decimal part of a number. The default is a dot.#{\newline[1em]\text{Decimal Separator:\enspace comma,\enspace} => \frac{1}{2} = 0,5#}
helperText.setThousandsSeparator: Separator of the thousands part of a number. The default is a comma.#{\newline[1em]\text{Thousands Separator: dot\enspace} => 1.000 = 1000#}
helperText.interpretAsInterval: This handles the case when the expected answer is specified as an interval, but the student neglects to include the surrounding parenthesis. This may also help in some cases where the entry is a x,y coordinate, a vector, a set, or a list. Note that you can also use parenthesis for the appropriate form, e.g. {0,1,2,3} is a set, [0,1,2] is a list, <0,1> is a vector, and (-10,0) is a coordinate point. For intervals such as (a,b), a must be less than b. Use rounded parenthesis for not including the ends, or square parenthesis for inclusion, e.g. [0,1].#{\newline[1em]\text{Expected:\enspace}(0,1)\newline[1em]#} If the student enters 0,1 then this will be considered as correct.
helperText.complexType: A combination of a real and an imaginary number in the form #{a + bi#}. This option is needed when the evaluation can handle complex evaluations. #{\newline[1em]\text{Expected:\enspace}(1+i)^2: 2i\newline[0.5em]#} would be considered as correct.
helperText.interpretAsSet: A collection of distinct objects separated by commas. Order is not considered. This option also supports partial credit scoring.#{\newline[1em]\text{Expected:\enspace}2,4,5 => \text{Correct:\enspace}5,4,2 ,\quad \text{Incorrect:\enspace} 2,4,6#}
helperText.interpretAsList: An ordered set of distinct objects separated by commas.#{\newline[1em]\text{Expected:\enspace}2,4,5 => \text{Correct:\enspace}2,4,5\quad\text{Incorrect:\enspace}2,5,4#}
helperText.allowEulersNumber: Any "#{e#}" in an expression will be interpreted as the same as the exponential function.#{\newline[1em]\text{Expected:\enspace}x\newline[0.5em]\text{Correct:\enspace}\ln e^x#}
helperText.interpretTrigArgAsDegree: Trigonometric function arguments are treated as degrees. The default is radians.#{\newline[1em]\text{Expected:\enspace}\sin(90)\newline[0.35em]\text{Correct:\enspace}1,\quad\text{Incorrect:\enspace}0#}
helperText.interpretAsImaginary: Interprets "#{i#}" as the square root of -1.#{\newline[1em]\text{Expected:\enspace}2i\newline[0.35em]\text{Equivalent:\enspace}(i+1)^2#}
helperText.interpretAsNumber: This handles case of commas and other separators that might cause ambiguity in the grading. For example, '1,123' will be the number One Thousand One Hundred and Twenty Three, and not the two numbers 1 and 123
helperText.ignoreCase: Variables in an expression are considered equivalent in either upper or lower case.#{\newline[1em]\text{Expected:\enspace}L=W\times H\newline[0.35em]\text{Correct:\enspace}l=w\times h#}.
helperText.ignoreAlphabeticCharacters: Any alphabetic characters in the response will be ignored.
helperText.allowedVariables: Students can only use the list of variables that are specified.#{\newline[1em]\text{Example:\enspace}x,y#}
helperText.allowNumericOnly: Only Numbers can be entered in the response box
helperText.ignoreVariableNames: Variables in an expression can have different names in the student response.#{\newline[1em]\text{Expected:\enspace}x+3=8\newline[0.5em]\text{Correct:\enspace}y+3=8,\quad\text{Wrong:\enspace}y-3=8#}
helperText.compareSides: This is often used in a CLOZE question type where there are connected entries separated by an in/equality. The evaluation separately considers both sides, e.g. “LHS=LHS & RHS=RHS”. Note that prior to evaluation, the sense of the inequality will be aligned between the student's response and the expected answer.#{\newline[1em]\text{Expected:\enspace}3+4=7\newline[0.5em]\text{Correct:\enspace}4+3=7,\quad\text{Wrong:\enspace}4+3=8#}
helperText.ignoreTrailingZeros: For example, 2.0+x is the same as 2+x
helperText.ignoreOrder: For example: 1,2,3 will be the same as 3,2,1
helperText.ignoreCoefficientOfOne: For example: y+1x is the same as y+x
helperText.ignoreLeadingAndTrailingSpaces: This will ignore any extra white space in the students response. For example 1+2 is the same as 1  +  2
helperText.applyRule: These are only checking the format of the student entry such as if it is an integer. It will not check the value of the integer. Some of the options come with an argument such as the number of decimal places.
helperText.automatic: The grading system will automatically infer a form. It most cases it will work fine, but you should check the preview mode with cases that are correct and incorrect to make sure the grading works as you expect. Otherwise you will need to override the context by explicitly providing the format.
helperText.compareStartPoint: The first point entered for the segment must match. It could also be the lowest alphabetic label, e.g. A.
helperText.comparePoints=False: Both points on the segment must match.
helperText.compareLength: The length of the segment must match. You can also combine this option with start point.
helperText.isParallel: Student must enter a line that is parallel to the given answer
helperText.isPerpendicular: Student must enter a line that is perpindicular to the given answer
helperText.compareArea: Student must enter a polygon with the same area
helperText.isSquare: Student must create a square polygon
helperText.isCongruent: The student polygon must have the same angles and sides, but the position and orientation can be different
helperText.isSimilar: The student polygon must have all their angles matching and the corresponding sides are in the same ratio
helperText.hasRightAngle: There is a right angle in the student polygon
helperText.comparePoints: All points in the student entry must match
helperText.comparePerimeter: The student object must have the same perimeter
helperText.ignoreLabels: If the objects have labels, then they will be considered in the evaluation, unless you select this option.
helperText.equationForms:
Forms of lines and conic sections:#{
ewline[1em]	ext{Line Standard Form:\enspace}ax+by=c
ewline	ext{Line Slope Intercept Form:\enspace}y=ax+b
ewline	ext{Line Point Slope Form:\enspace}(y-b)=c(x-a)
ewline	ext{Quadratic Standard Form:\enspace}ax^2+bx+c=0
ewline	ext{Polynomial Standard Form:\enspace}\Sigma(a_ix^i)=0#} where the #{a_i#} are the coeficients and #{i#} is the degree of the polynomial#{
ewline	ext{Polynomial Factored Form\enspace}\Pi(x-a_i)=0
ewline[1em]	ext{Conic Standard Forms:}
ewline[0.5em]	ext{Circle:\enspace}(x-h)^2+(y-k)^2=r^2
ewline[0.3em]	ext{Ellipse:\enspace} rac{(x-h)^2}{a^2}+ rac{(y-k)^2}{b^2}=1
ewline[0.3em]	ext{Hyperbola:\enspace} rac{(x-h)^2}{a^2}- rac{(y-k)^2}{b^2}=1
ewline[.3em]	ext{Parabola:\enspace}4p(y-k)=(x-h)^2
ewline[1em]	ext{Parabola Vertex Form:\enspace}y=a(x-h)^2+k
ewline	ext{\enspace( x or y can be on LHS)}#}
helperText.updateOrDeleteCustomKeypad: Removed keypad (and older version of the keypad in the case of you edit a keypad) will not be available for future questions and test setting. Old content will continue to have the same keypad until question is saved with new keypad again.
helperText.saveCustomKeypad: Save your custom keypad to use on future questions. It will appear as an option in the Choose Keypad dropdown

audioResponse.scoringMessage: [Audio responses can only be manually graded]
